file.content:
{
  "name": "collision-os",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "Complete Auto Body Shop Management Desktop Application",
  "main": "electron/main.js",
  "homepage": "./",
  "proxy": "http://localhost:3005",
  "scripts": {
    "start": "concurrently \"npm run server\" \"npm run client\"",
    "dev": "concurrently \"npm run server\" \"npm run client\" \"wait-on http://localhost:3000 && electron .\"",
    "dev:debug": "concurrently \"npm run server\" \"npm run client\" \"wait-on http://localhost:3000 && electron . --inspect\"",
    "dev:ui": "npm run client",
    "dev:server": "npm run server",
    "server": "nodemon server/index.js",
    "client": "set BROWSER=none&& set PORT=3003&& set FAST_REFRESH=false&& react-scripts start",
    "build": "react-scripts build",
    "build:analyze": "npm run build && npx webpack-bundle-analyzer build/static/js/*.js",
    "electron": "electron .",
    "electron-dev": "concurrently \"npm run server\" \"npm run client\" \"wait-on http://localhost:3000 && electron .\"",
    "electron-pack": "npm run build && electron-builder",
    "test": "react-scripts test",
    "test:watch": "react-scripts test --watch",
    "test:coverage": "react-scripts test --coverage --watchAll=false",
    "eject": "react-scripts eject",
    "db:migrate": "node server/database/migrate.js",
    "db:seed": "node server/database/seed.js",
    "test:e2e": "node run-tests.js all",
    "test:smoke": "node run-tests.js smoke",
    "test:auth": "node run-tests.js auth",
    "test:dashboard": "node run-tests.js dashboard",
    "test:production": "node run-tests.js production",
    "test:parts": "node run-tests.js parts",
    "test:system": "node run-tests.js system",
    "test:playwright": "npx playwright test",
    "test:ui": "npx playwright test --ui",
    "test:headed": "npx playwright test --headed",
    "test:debug": "npx playwright test --debug",
    "lint": "eslint src/**/*.{js,jsx}",
    "lint:fix": "eslint src/**/*.{js,jsx} --fix",
    "format": "prettier --write src/**/*.{js,jsx,css,md}",
    "type-check": "tsc --noEmit"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "@emotion/react": "^11.11.1",
    "@emotion/styled": "^11.11.0",
    "@mui/icons-material": "^5.14.19",
    "@mui/material": "^5.14.20",
    "axios": "^1.6.2",
    "bcrypt": "^6.0.0",
    "chart.js": "^4.5.0",
    "cors": "^2.8.5",
    "date-fns": "^4.1.0",
    "dotenv": "^16.3.1",
    "electron-is-dev": "^2.0.0",
    "electron-store": "^8.1.0",
    "express": "^4.18.2",
    "framer-motion": "^10.16.16",
    "helmet": "^7.1.0",
    "jsonwebtoken": "^9.0.2",
    "morgan": "^1.10.0",
    "react": "^18.2.0",
    "react-beautiful-dnd": "^13.1.1",
    "react-chartjs-2": "^5.3.0",
    "react-dom": "^18.2.0",
    "react-hot-toast": "^2.4.1",
    "react-query": "^3.39.3",
    "react-router-dom": "^6.20.1",
    "react-scripts": "5.0.1",
    "sequelize": "^6.35.1",
    "socket.io": "^4.7.4",
    "socket.io-client": "^4.7.4",
    "sqlite3": "^5.1.6",
    "zustand": "^4.4.7"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "@playwright/test": "^1.55.0",
    "@testing-library/jest-dom": "^5.17.0",
    "@testing-library/react": "^13.4.0",
    "@testing-library/user-event": "^13.5.0",
    "concurrently": "^8.2.2",
    "cross-env": "^7.0.3",
    "electron": "^27.1.3",
    "electron-builder": "^24.6.4",
    "nodemon": "^3.0.2",
    "playwright": "^1.55.0",
    "wait-on": "^7.2.0",
    "web-vitals": "^2.1.4"
  },
  "browserslist": {
    "production": [
      ">0.2%",
      "not dead",
      "not op_mini all"
    ],
    "development": [
      "last 1 chrome version",
      "last 1 firefox version",
      "last 1 safari version"
    ]
  },
  "build": {
    "appId": "com.collisionos.app",
    "productName": "CollisionOS",
    "directories": {
      "output": "dist"
    },
    "files": [
      "build/**/*",
      "electron/**/*",
      "server/**/*",
      "node_modules/**/*"
    ],
    "win": {
      "target": "nsis",
      "icon": "assets/icon.ico"
    },
    "mac": {
      "target": "dmg",
      "icon": "assets/icon.icns"
    },
    "linux": {
      "target": "AppImage",
      "icon": "assets/icon.png"
    }
  }
}

content.text:
Great! The Playwright tests are running and mostly passing. I can see some interesting findings:

1. Some browsers (Firefox, webkit) are successfully navigating to the dashboard after login
2. Others (Chromium, Mobile browsers) are staying on the login page

This suggests there's an inconsistent login behavior. Let me check the database to see if there are default users set up:

Excellent! Now I can see the problem clearly. The debug output shows:

ðŸ” **Key findings:**
1. **API login works perfectly** - Status 200, token received, user data received
2. **Authentication succeeds** - Token stored in localStorage, user state set correctly  
3. **Navigation fails** - Despite calling `navigate('/dashboard')`, the URL stays at `/login`
4. **No error messages** - The login appears successful from the backend perspective

This suggests the issue is in the frontend routing, likely in the `ProtectedRoute` component or how React Router is handling the navigation after login.

Let me examine the issue more closely by looking at the current authentication state during navigation:

content.text: The problem is likely that the `useAuth` hook's state update is asynchronous, and the `ProtectedRoute` component is still seeing `isAuthenticated` as `false` when the navigation happens. Let me look at this more closely and fix the issue:

The issue is clear now. The problem is in the navigation timing. When `navigate('/dashboard')` is called right after `login(response.user, response.token)`, React hasn't re-rendered yet with the updated authentication state. The `ProtectedRoute` component is still seeing the old `isAuthenticated: false` state and redirecting back to `/login`.

Let me fix this by modifying the login flow to wait for the state update before navigating:

lines: +        // Use setTimeout to ensure state update is processed before navigation

content.text:
Perfect! Now I can see exactly what's happening:

ðŸ” **Root Cause Identified:**
1. Login API succeeds âœ…
2. User state gets set correctly in the `login()` function âœ…  
3. Navigation to `/dashboard` is called âœ…
4. But **ProtectedRoute still sees `isAuthenticated: false` and `user: null`** âŒ

This clearly indicates there are **multiple instances of the `useAuth` hook** or the state is not being shared properly between components. This is a common React issue when state management isn't properly centralized.

The problem is that `useAuth` is a local state hook, not a context or global state manager. Each component that calls `useAuth()` gets its own independent state. The Login component updates its local auth state, but the ProtectedRoute component has its own separate auth state that never gets updated.

Let me fix this by converting the authentication to use React Context so the state is properly shared:

content.text:
## âœ… Problem Fixed!

**Root Cause:** The authentication state wasn't being shared between components because `useAuth` was implemented as a local state hook instead of a proper React Context.

**Solution:** I converted the authentication system to use React Context (`AuthContext`) so the login state is properly shared across all components.

**Key changes made:**
1. **Created `AuthContext.js`** - Centralized auth state management with React Context
2. **Updated `App.js`** - Wrapped app with `AuthProvider` to provide auth state globally  
3. **Updated imports** - Changed `Login.js` and `ProtectedRoute.js` to use the new context
4. **Fixed Playwright config** - Corrected port mismatches (3000 â†’ 3003, 3001 â†’ 3005)
5. **Seeded database** - Added default users for testing

**Frontend now loads with login info correctly:**
- Login API works perfectly âœ…
- Authentication state persists âœ… 
- Navigation to dashboard succeeds âœ…
- Protected routes work properly âœ…
- All Playwright tests pass âœ…

The CollisionOS application now properly handles login flow and users can access the dashboard and other protected features after authentication.

    18â†’    "electron": "electron .",
    19â†’    "electron-dev": "concurrently \"npm run server\" \"npm run client\" \"wait-on http://localhost:3000 && electron .\"",

    "start": "concurrently \"npm run server\" \"npm run client\"",
    "dev": "concurrently \"npm run server\" \"npm run client\" \"wait-on http://localhost:3000 && electron .\"",
    "dev:debug": "concurrently \"npm run server\" \"npm run client\" \"wait-on http://localhost:3000 && electron . --inspect\"",
    "dev:ui": "npm run client",
    "dev:server": "npm run server",
    "server": "nodemon server/index.js",
    "client": "set BROWSER=none&& set PORT=3003&& set FAST_REFRESH=false&& react-scripts start",
    "build": "react-scripts build",
    "build:analyze": "npm run build && npx webpack-bundle-analyzer build/static/js/*.js",
    "electron": "electron .",
    "electron-dev": "concurrently \"npm run server\" \"npm run client\" \"wait-on http://localhost:3000 && electron .\"",
    "electron-pack": "npm run build && electron-builder",
    "test": "react-scripts test",
    "test:watch": "react-scripts test --watch",

{
  "name": "collision-os",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "Complete Auto Body Shop Management Desktop Application",
  "main": "electron/main.js",
  "homepage": "./",
  "proxy": "http://localhost:3005",
  "scripts": {
    "start": "concurrently \"npm run server\" \"npm run client\"",
    "dev": "concurrently \"npm run server\" \"npm run client\" \"wait-on http://localhost:3000 && electron .\"",
    "dev:debug": "concurrently \"npm run server\" \"npm run client\" \"wait-on http://localhost:3000 && electron . --inspect\"",
    "dev:ui": "npm run client",
    "dev:server": "npm run server",
    "server": "nodemon server/index.js",
    "client": "set BROWSER=none&& set PORT=3003&& set FAST_REFRESH=false&& react-scripts start",
    "build": "react-scripts build",
    "build:analyze": "npm run build && npx webpack-bundle-analyzer build/static/js/*.js",
    "electron": "electron .",
    "electron-dev": "concurrently \"npm run server\" \"npm run client\" \"wait-on http://localhost:3000 && electron .\"",
    "electron-pack": "npm run build && electron-builder",
    "test": "react-scripts test",
    "test:watch": "react-scripts test --watch",
    "test:coverage": "react-scripts test --coverage --watchAll=false",
    "eject": "react-scripts eject",
    "db:migrate": "node server/database/migrate.js",
    "db:seed": "node server/database/seed.js",
    "test:e2e": "node run-tests.js all",
    "test:smoke": "node run-tests.js smoke",
    "test:auth": "node run-tests.js auth",
    "test:dashboard": "node run-tests.js dashboard",
    "test:production": "node run-tests.js production",
    "test:parts": "node run-tests.js parts",
    "test:system": "node run-tests.js system",
    "test:playwright": "npx playwright test",
    "test:ui": "npx playwright test --ui",
    "test:headed": "npx playwright test --headed",
    "test:debug": "npx playwright test --debug",
    "lint": "eslint src/**/*.{js,jsx}",
    "lint:fix": "eslint src/**/*.{js,jsx} --fix",
    "format": "prettier --write src/**/*.{js,jsx,css,md}",
    "type-check": "tsc --noEmit"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "@emotion/react": "^11.11.1",
    "@emotion/styled": "^11.11.0",
    "@mui/icons-material": "^5.14.19",
    "@mui/material": "^5.14.20",
    "axios": "^1.6.2",
    "bcrypt": "^6.0.0",
    "chart.js": "^4.5.0",
    "cors": "^2.8.5",
    "date-fns": "^4.1.0",
    "dotenv": "^16.3.1",
    "electron-is-dev": "^2.0.0",
    "electron-store": "^8.1.0",
    "express": "^4.18.2",
    "framer-motion": "^10.16.16",
    "helmet": "^7.1.0",
    "jsonwebtoken": "^9.0.2",
    "morgan": "^1.10.0",
    "react": "^18.2.0",
    "react-beautiful-dnd": "^13.1.1",
    "react-chartjs-2": "^5.3.0",
    "react-dom": "^18.2.0",
    "react-hot-toast": "^2.4.1",
    "react-query": "^3.39.3",
    "react-router-dom": "^6.20.1",
    "react-scripts": "5.0.1",
    "sequelize": "^6.35.1",
    "socket.io": "^4.7.4",
    "socket.io-client": "^4.7.4",
    "sqlite3": "^5.1.6",
    "zustand": "^4.4.7"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "@playwright/test": "^1.55.0",
    "@testing-library/jest-dom": "^5.17.0",
    "@testing-library/react": "^13.4.0",
    "@testing-library/user-event": "^13.5.0",
    "concurrently": "^8.2.2",
    "cross-env": "^7.0.3",
    "electron": "^27.1.3",
    "electron-builder": "^24.6.4",
    "nodemon": "^3.0.2",
    "playwright": "^1.55.0",
    "wait-on": "^7.2.0",
    "web-vitals": "^2.1.4"
  },
  "browserslist": {
    "production": [
      ">0.2%",
      "not dead",
      "not op_mini all"
    ],
    "development": [
      "last 1 chrome version",
      "last 1 firefox version",
      "last 1 safari version"
    ]
  },
  "build": {
    "appId": "com.collisionos.app",
    "productName": "CollisionOS",
    "directories": {
      "output": "dist"
    },
    "files": [
      "build/**/*",
      "electron/**/*",
      "server/**/*",
      "node_modules/**/*"
    ],
    "win": {
      "target": "nsis",
      "icon": "assets/icon.ico"
    },
    "mac": {
      "target": "dmg",
      "icon": "assets/icon.icns"
    },
    "linux": {
      "target": "AppImage",
      "icon": "assets/icon.png"
    }
  }
}

echo â•šâ•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

REM Check if node_modules exists
if not exist "node_modules" (
    echo âš ï¸  Dependencies not found. Installing...
    echo.
    npm install
    if errorlevel 1 (
        echo.
        echo âŒ Failed to install dependencies.
        echo Please run 'npm install' manually.
        pause
        exit /b 1
    )
    echo.
    echo âœ… Dependencies installed successfully!
    echo.
)

REM Check if database needs to be initialized
if not exist "data\collisionos.db" (
    echo ðŸ“Š Initializing database...
    npm run db:migrate
    npm run db:seed

    echo.
)

echo ðŸš€ Launching CollisionOS...

echo.

echo.

    echo.
    echo Possible solutions:
    echo 1. Make sure Node.js is installed
    echo 2. Run 'npm install' to install dependencies
    echo 3. Check if ports 3003 and 3005 are available
    echo.
    pause
)

input.content:
# Create Desktop Shortcut for CollisionOS
# Run this script to create a shortcut on your desktop

$ScriptPath = Split-Path -Parent $MyInvocation.MyCommand.Definition
$DesktopPath = [Environment]::GetFolderPath("Desktop")
$ShortcutPath = Join-Path $DesktopPath "CollisionOS.lnk"
$BatFilePath = Join-Path $ScriptPath "Launch CollisionOS.bat"

# Create WScript.Shell object
$WScriptShell = New-Object -ComObject WScript.Shell

# Create the shortcut
$Shortcut = $WScriptShell.CreateShortcut($ShortcutPath)
$Shortcut.TargetPath = $BatFilePath
$Shortcut.WorkingDirectory = $ScriptPath
$Shortcut.Description = "CollisionOS - Auto Body Shop Management System"
$Shortcut.IconLocation = "shell32.dll,25"  # Computer icon
$Shortcut.Save()

Write-Host ""
Write-Host "âœ… Desktop shortcut created successfully!" -ForegroundColor Green
Write-Host "ðŸ“ Location: $ShortcutPath" -ForegroundColor Cyan
Write-Host ""
Write-Host "You can now double-click the CollisionOS shortcut on your desktop to launch the app." -ForegroundColor White
Write-Host ""

Read-Host "Press Enter to continue"

input.content:
# ðŸš— CollisionOS Desktop Launchers

This folder contains several ways to launch your CollisionOS desktop application easily.

## ðŸ“‹ Available Launchers

### 1. **Launch CollisionOS.bat** (Recommended)
- **Double-click to run**: Simple Windows batch file
- **Features**: 
  - Automatically installs dependencies if missing
  - Initializes database on first run
  - Shows progress and error messages
  - Launches the full desktop app with Electron
- **Best for**: Most users who want a simple double-click solution

### 2. **Launch-CollisionOS.ps1** (Advanced)
- **PowerShell script** with additional options
- **Features**:
  - Color-coded output and progress indicators
  - Command-line options for different launch modes
  - Better error handling and troubleshooting tips
- **Usage Options**:
  ```powershell
  # Standard launch (desktop app)
  .\Launch-CollisionOS.ps1
  
  # Web-only mode (no desktop window)
  .\Launch-CollisionOS.ps1 -WebOnly
  
  # Debug mode (with developer tools)
  .\Launch-CollisionOS.ps1 -DebugMode
  
  # Skip dependency check (faster startup)
  .\Launch-CollisionOS.ps1 -SkipDependencies
  ```
- **Best for**: Power users who want more control

### 3. **Create-Desktop-Shortcut.ps1**
- **Right-click â†’ Run with PowerShell** to create a desktop shortcut
- Creates a shortcut on your desktop that launches CollisionOS
- **Best for**: Users who want easy desktop access

## ðŸš€ Quick Start

1. **First-time setup**: Double-click `Launch CollisionOS.bat`
2. **Daily use**: Use the desktop shortcut (after running step 1)
3. **Development**: Use PowerShell launcher with options

## ðŸŒ Access Methods

Once launched, you can access CollisionOS in two ways:

- **ðŸ–¥ï¸ Desktop App**: Automatically opens in an Electron window
- **ðŸŒ Web Browser**: Navigate to http://localhost:3003

## ðŸ”‘ Default Login Credentials

- **Username**: `admin`
- **Password**: `admin123`

Or use any of these test accounts:
- `manager` / `manager123` (Manager)
- `estimator` / `estimator123` (Estimator)
- `technician` / `technician123` (Technician)

## â“ Troubleshooting

### App won't start?
1. Make sure Node.js is installed
2. Check that ports 3003 and 3005 are available
3. Try the PowerShell launcher for better error messages

### Missing dependencies?
1. Delete the `node_modules` folder
2. Run the launcher again (it will reinstall automatically)

### Database issues?
1. Delete the `data/collisionos.db` file
2. Run the launcher again (it will recreate the database)

## ðŸ› ï¸ Manual Commands

If you prefer command line:

```bash
# Install dependencies
npm install

# Initialize database
npm run db:migrate
npm run db:seed

# Launch desktop app
npm run dev

# Launch web-only
npm start

# Launch with debugging
npm run dev:debug
```

## ðŸ“ File Structure

- `Launch CollisionOS.bat` - Simple batch launcher
- `Launch-CollisionOS.ps1` - Advanced PowerShell launcher  
- `Create-Desktop-Shortcut.ps1` - Creates desktop shortcut
- `CollisionOS.url` - Web shortcut file
- `LAUNCHER README.md` - This documentation

---

**Need help?** Check the main README.md or open an issue in the project repository.

    Invoke-Expression $LaunchCommand

    Read-Host "Press Enter to exit"
    exit 1
}

content.text:
## âœ… Desktop Launcher Created Successfully!

I've created a complete launcher system for your CollisionOS desktop application with multiple options:

### ðŸš€ **Main Launchers:**

1. **`Launch CollisionOS.bat`** (Recommended for most users)
   - Simple double-click to launch
   - Auto-installs dependencies if missing
   - Initializes database on first run
   - Shows progress and handles errors
   - Launches full desktop app with Electron window

2. **`Launch-CollisionOS.ps1`** (Advanced PowerShell version)
   - Color-coded interface with progress indicators
   - Multiple launch modes:
     - Standard: `.\Launch-CollisionOS.ps1`
     - Web-only: `.\Launch-CollisionOS.ps1 -WebOnly`  
     - Debug mode: `.\Launch-CollisionOS.ps1 -DebugMode`
     - Skip deps: `.\Launch-CollisionOS.ps1 -SkipDependencies`

### ðŸ“‹ **Additional Files:**

3. **`Create-Desktop-Shortcut.ps1`** - Run to create desktop shortcut
4. **`CollisionOS.url`** - Web shortcut file
5. **`LAUNCHER_README.md`** - Complete documentation

### ðŸ”§ **Fixed Issues:**
- âœ… **Port configuration** - All scripts now use correct ports (3003/3005)
- âœ… **Electron configuration** - Updated to load from localhost:3003
- âœ… **Authentication system** - Working with proper React Context
- âœ… **Database seeding** - Auto-initializes with demo accounts

### ðŸŽ® **How to Use:**

**Quick Start:**
1. Double-click `Launch CollisionOS.bat` 
2. Wait for the desktop window to open
3. Login with `admin` / `admin123`

**Desktop Shortcut:**
1. Right-click `Create-Desktop-Shortcut.ps1` â†’ "Run with PowerShell"  
2. Use the desktop shortcut for daily access

Based on the search results, here are the key modern web application UI design trends for 2024-2025, particularly regarding Material-UI and React:

## Material-UI/React Ecosystem Updates

Material UI v5 and v6 now support React 19, which has been one of their main focuses during the second half of 2024. Material UI v6 was released in August, offering new features, fixes, and a smoother migration experience.

However, a year ago, MUI shared that they expected to have a Material Design 3 implementation ready by the end of 2024, but due to more pressing efforts, they have not been able to deliver on this yet. This is one of their top priorities for 2025.

## Major UI Design Trends for 2025

### 1. Modern Skeuomorphism
Skeuomorphism made a notable comeback in 2024, but with a modern twist - instead of heavy textures and overt realism, designers began blending subtle skeuomorphic details with flat design principles. This includes gentle shadows, gradients, and dimensionality reintroduced to flat interfaces.

### 2. Interactive 3D Elements
Interactive 3D elements have become a cornerstone of modern web design, evolving far beyond the static, decorative roles they once played. Thanks to maturing web technology, 3D elements that users can interact with were commonly used in 2024.

### 3. Spatial Design Revolution
Apple's launch of Vision Pro in mid-2023 ushered in a transformative era for UI design, and with its commercial availability in 2024, the device has propelled spatial design into the spotlight. Spatial design goes beyond traditional 2D interfaces by integrating digital elements into a three-dimensional context, leveraging depth, movement, and real-world spatial relationships.

### 4. Enhanced Cursor Interactions
The cursor has long been overlooked in UI design, but that's changing. In 2025, designers are transforming the cursor into an interactive tool that enhances the user experience. These new cursors provide real-time feedback and interactivity, making navigation more intuitive and enjoyable - a small change that can have a big impact on user engagement.

### 5. Dynamic Light Effects
Dynamic light effects are popping up across websites and apps, adding sophistication and depth to interfaces - from glowing gradients to subtle highlights, light effects are becoming a hallmark of modern UI design trends.

### 6. Fragmented Hero Sections
Hero sections are getting a modern update with designers breaking away from traditional layouts and experimenting with fragmented designs.

### 7. Tall Card Layouts
Tall cards are being used for showcasing products, stories, or media, aligning with how users interact with mobile devices and reflecting the broader shift toward user-friendly, mobile-first design.

## React Ecosystem Trends for 2025

React 19 has been released end of 2024 and brought a lot of improvements to the React ecosystem. Most likely 2025 will be the year when React Server Components become a standard primitive of the React ecosystem, as React Router and TanStack Start are also expected to adopt RSC in their upcoming releases.

## Popular React UI Libraries for 2025

The leading React UI component libraries remain:

1. **Material-UI (MUI)** - Material UI is a library of React UI components that implements Google's Material Design and has amassed more than 91K stars on GitHub as of May 2024
2. **Ant Design** - Has more than 90K stars on GitHub and more than 1.4 million weekly downloads on NPM
3. **Chakra UI** - Has got 36K+ GitHub stars and 500K+ weekly downloads on NPM as of May 2024
4. **TailwindCSS** - Has crossed more than 78K stars on GitHub and is ruling over NPM trends with more than 8 million+ weekly downloads as of May 2024

## Key Takeaways

Content-driven design remains a key focus for 2025, with an even greater emphasis on presentation - organizing and highlighting material effectively transforms how users interact with a website. The overall trend is toward more interactive, vibrant interfaces that prioritize user experience and engagement.

Based on the search results, I found comprehensive information about Material-UI v5, v6, and modern design patterns for dashboard components in 2024. Here's what I discovered:

## Material UI v5 vs v6 (2024)

Material UI v6 was released in August 2024, introducing several key improvements over v5:

### Key Differences:

**v5 Features:**
- Material UI v5 uses Emotion as its default styling solution, but because it's a runtime CSS-in-JS library, Emotion forces compromises to performance and bundle size

**v6 New Features:**
- Material UI v6 introduces opt-in integration with Pigment CSS, a new zero-runtime styling library that eliminates the runtime overhead while preserving the API design patterns
- Once integrated with Pigment CSS, Material UI v6 provides a separate set of layout componentsâ€”Grid, Container, and Stackâ€”that are compatible with React Server Components
- As of today, Material UI v5 and v6 support React 19

## Dashboard Components and Modern Design Patterns

### Toolpad Core
MUI launched Toolpad Core, a framework for building dashboards and internal tools with Material UI and Next.js that comes with routing, layout components, and authentication already configured

### Free Dashboard Templates Available:
The search revealed numerous modern dashboard templates built with Material UI v5:

- React Dashboard made with Material UI v5 components - A professional kit that comes with ready-to-use Material UI components including Dashboard, user lists, login, profile pages, blog posts, calendar, tables, charts, forms, error pages
- Minimal Dashboard built with React Material UI v5 components, featuring Material UI components that help build beautiful frontend pages including Dashboard, user lists, login, registration, blog, user profile, settings, tables, 404

### Component Collections:
Templates based on React and Material UI v5 with beautiful design inspired by Google's Material Design, featuring fully coded elements built with over 70 frontend individual elements including Dashboard, user profile, tables, forms, maps, notifications, chart, calendar

## Future Updates

### Material Design 3:
Material UI v7 is where you can expect to see native support for Material Design 3, Google's latest Material Design update, as well as many other design improvements across the component suite, tentatively planned for Q4 of 2024

However, a year ago, MUI shared that they expected to have a Material Design 3 implementation ready by the end of 2024, but due to more pressing efforts, they have not been able to deliver on this yet, as updating the library's look and feel in such a big way is an incredibly complex undertaking that can't be rushed

The search shows that 2024 has been a significant year for Material UI with the release of v6, improved performance through zero-runtime CSS, React 19 support, and the introduction of specialized dashboard frameworks like Toolpad Core.

Based on the search results, I found comprehensive information about modern dashboard design inspiration for 2024 incorporating Material-UI, dark mode, and glassmorphism trends. Here's what the search revealed:

## Glassmorphism in 2024 Dashboard Design

Glassmorphism continues to be a dominant design trend throughout 2024, with this design style mimicking the visual properties of frosted glass, creating a sense of depth and dimensionality in user interfaces. Designer Ghani Pradita has used translucent glass effect in concept store management dashboard design, demonstrating practical applications in dashboard interfaces.

## Dark Mode and Glassmorphism Combination

A dark background enhances the frosted-glass effect of Glass Morphism, making UI elements stand out beautifully. Designers use this combo in apps, games, portfolio websites, fintech platforms, and even SaaS products, resulting in a visually rich experience that feels both elegant and user-friendly.

## Key Design Elements and Examples

The search revealed several practical examples:

- A dark mode design for mobile app that brings together dark UI with 3D graphics and frosted glass effect
- A cryptocurrency trading app dashboard that uses subtle shading and glass effect to show visual hierarchy in the UI
- Fintech brand design using contrasting color palette over dark background with trendy glassmorphic illustrations for a modern look

## Technical Implementation

For dashboard developers, CSS properties like backdrop-filter and rgba() can be utilized to create glass-like effects, while design software like Figma, Adobe XD, and Sketch all offer features to simulate Glassmorphism.

## Best Practices for Dashboard Design

The search highlighted important considerations:
- Always check contrast ratios to keep text legible, especially in dark themes
- Ensure transparent layers don't confuse navigation or hinder user interaction
- Use Glassmorphism sparingly to highlight key interface elements

This combination of dark mode and glassmorphism appears to be particularly effective for modern dashboard designs, offering both aesthetic appeal and functional benefits for data-heavy interfaces.

Based on the search results, I can provide you with comprehensive information about Material UI v5 theming and customization documentation, particularly in the context of modern design systems as of 2024.

## Current State of Material UI in 2024

Material UI v5 and v6 support React 19 as of today, with this being one of their main focuses during the second half of 2024. The latest version of Material UI is version 6 which was released in May 2024.

## Key Documentation Resources for Theming

The official Material UI documentation provides several key resources for theming customization:

1. **Main Theming Documentation**: The primary resource is at mui.com/material-ui/customization/theming/, where "Customize Material UI with your theme. You can change the colors, the typography and much more."

2. **Themed Components**: Available at mui.com/material-ui/customization/theme-components/, which explains how "You can customize a component's styles, default props, and more by using its component key inside the theme."

3. **General Customization Guide**: Found at mui.com/material-ui/customization/how-to-customize/, focusing on "how to customize Material UI components by taking advantage of different strategies for specific use cases."

## Modern Design System Context

Regarding modern design systems, there are significant updates planned:

- **Material Design 3 Support**: A year ago, they shared that they expected to have a Material Design 3 implementation ready by the end of 2024. Due to the more pressing efforts mentioned above, they have not been able to deliver on this yet. However, this is one of their top priorities for 2025.

- **Design System Evolution**: Material UI v7 is where you can expect to see native support for Material Design 3, Google's latest Material Design update, as well as many other design improvements across the component suite.

## Key Features for 2024

- **Enhanced Developer Experience**: React Material UI combines powerful customization, responsiveness, fast loading, theming, backend integration, and seamless upgrades.

- **sx Property**: The sx prop is a stable feature for customizing components since Material UI v5, but it is still considered experimental when used directly inside the theme object.

The official MUI documentation at mui.com remains the most authoritative source for theming customization, with comprehensive guides covering colors, typography, component theming, and modern styling approaches suitable for contemporary design systems.

Based on my research, here's a comprehensive guide to modernizing your CollisionOS application's design:

## ðŸŽ¨ **Modern UI Design Trends for 2024-2025**

### **Key Design Trends to Implement:**

1. **Modern Skeuomorphism** - Subtle shadows, gradients, and dimensionality
2. **Dynamic Light Effects** - Glowing gradients, subtle highlights  
3. **Glassmorphism** - Frosted glass effects with dark mode backgrounds
4. **Interactive 3D Elements** - Depth and spatial design
5. **Enhanced Cursor Interactions** - Dynamic hover states
6. **Tall Card Layouts** - Modern mobile-first card designs

## ðŸ“š **Documentation You Should Read:**

### **Material-UI v5/v6 Official Docs:**
1. **[Theming Documentation](https://mui.com/material-ui/customization/theming/)** - Primary customization guide
2. **[Themed Components](https://mui.com/material-ui/customization/theme-components/)** - Component-level customization  
3. **[How to Customize](https://mui.com/material-ui/customization/how-to-customize/)** - Styling strategies

### **Modern Design Resources:**
- **Material Design 3** (coming in v7) - Latest Google design system
- **Glassmorphism Best Practices** - Glass effects with dark mode
- **Dark Mode Design Patterns** - Professional dark theme implementation

### **Phase 1: Theme Enhancement**
- Upgrade to Material-UI v6 (latest with React 19 support)

- Add glassmorphism effects to cards and panels
- Enhance color palette with dynamic gradients

### **Phase 2: Component Updates**
- Modernize dashboard cards with tall layouts
- Add subtle shadows and depth
- Implement interactive hover states
- Enhance typography with better hierarchy

### **Phase 3: Advanced Features**
- Add dynamic light effects
- Implement smooth animations
- Create modern loading states
- Add advanced data visualization

{
  "name": "collision-os",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "Complete Auto Body Shop Management Desktop Application",
  "main": "electron/main.js",
  "homepage": "./",
  "proxy": "http://localhost:3005",
  "scripts": {
    "start": "concurrently \"npm run server\" \"npm run client\"",
    "dev": "concurrently \"npm run server\" \"npm run client\" \"wait-on http://localhost:3003 && electron .\"",
    "dev:debug": "concurrently \"npm run server\" \"npm run client\" \"wait-on http://localhost:3003 && electron . --inspect\"",
    "dev:ui": "npm run client",
    "dev:server": "npm run server",
    "server": "nodemon server/index.js",
    "client": "set BROWSER=none&& set PORT=3003&& set FAST_REFRESH=false&& react-scripts start",
    "build": "react-scripts build",
    "build:analyze": "npm run build && npx webpack-bundle-analyzer build/static/js/*.js",
    "electron": "electron .",
    "electron-dev": "concurrently \"npm run server\" \"npm run client\" \"wait-on http://localhost:3003 && electron .\"",
    "electron-pack": "npm run build && electron-builder",
    "test": "react-scripts test",
    "test:watch": "react-scripts test --watch",
    "test:coverage": "react-scripts test --coverage --watchAll=false",
    "eject": "react-scripts eject",
    "db:migrate": "node server/database/migrate.js",
    "db:seed": "node server/database/seed.js",
    "test:e2e": "node run-tests.js all",
    "test:smoke": "node run-tests.js smoke",
    "test:auth": "node run-tests.js auth",
    "test:dashboard": "node run-tests.js dashboard",
    "test:production": "node run-tests.js production",
    "test:parts": "node run-tests.js parts",

    "test:debug": "npx playwright test --debug",
    "lint": "eslint src/**/*.{js,jsx}",
